1.name: Phase 1: Market Fit & Strategy
1.description: Define the critical pain points, unique value proposition, and competitive advantage of EG's retail AI solution.
1.contributors: VP of Merchandising, Store Managers, Inventory Planners, CFO

questions.text: What specific pain point are we solving that the customer cannot efficiently address today?
questions.criteria: Static forecasting limitations, demand signal blindness, inventory imbalance costs, working capital inefficiency, cross-channel visibility gaps
questions.focus: Identify the inability to respond dynamically to real-time demand signals and the cost of inventory misalignment.
questions.hint_text: Describe how retailers rely on static historical forecasting that misses sudden demand shifts. Mention the inability to synthesize real-time signals like weather, events, social trends, and competitor actions. Explain the financial impact of stockouts and overstock.
questions.ideal_answer: Retail teams struggle with inventory decisions based on static historical forecasts that cannot adapt to rapidly changing market conditions. Traditional planning systems miss critical real-time signals—weather patterns affecting seasonal products, local events driving demand spikes, social media trends creating unexpected surges, or competitor promotions shifting customer behavior. Buyers discover stockouts only when customers complain or sales data reveals missed opportunities, while simultaneously holding excess inventory of slow-moving products that tie up capital and eventually require markdowns. This disconnect between actual demand and inventory positioning results in lost revenue from empty shelves, eroded margins from clearance markdowns, and inefficient working capital deployment that constrains growth.

questions.text: What measurable value will the customer realize, and how quickly?
questions.criteria: Stockout reduction metrics, overstock decrease quantification, margin improvement visibility, working capital efficiency gains, forecast accuracy enhancement
questions.focus: Quantify inventory optimization impact on revenue capture and working capital efficiency with clear realization timeline.
questions.hint_text: Focus on how accurate demand prediction reduces both stockouts and overstock simultaneously. Mention the speed of improvement as the system begins processing real-time demand signals. Emphasize the dual benefit of revenue protection and capital efficiency.
questions.ideal_answer: Merchants see measurable improvements within the first replenishment cycles, with demand forecasts adapting to real-time signals and preventing stockouts on high-demand items while reducing overstock purchases. Stores experience fewer empty shelves during peak demand periods, capturing sales that would otherwise be lost to competitors. Simultaneously, inventory investments become more efficient as excess stock decreases, freeing working capital for more productive deployment. The financial impact manifests through improved sell-through rates, reduced markdown requirements, higher gross margins from full-price sales, and better inventory turns that strengthen cash flow and return on invested capital.

questions.text: Why is EG the right partner? What differentiates EG?
questions.criteria: Retail-specific demand modeling, real-time signal integration, multi-channel intelligence, localized prediction accuracy, implementation speed
questions.focus: Highlight retail domain expertise and real-time multi-signal correlation capabilities that generic forecasting tools cannot deliver.
questions.hint_text: Highlight AI trained specifically on retail demand patterns versus generic forecasting models. Contrast the ability to synthesize diverse real-time signals with traditional statistical approaches. Emphasize understanding of retail operations and merchandising workflows.
questions.ideal_answer: The solution delivers superior forecast accuracy through AI purpose-built for retail demand complexity, trained on diverse merchandise categories and seasonality patterns rather than generic time-series models. Unlike traditional forecasting tools that rely solely on historical sales, the platform continuously synthesizes real-time signals—weather patterns, local events, social sentiment, competitive pricing, and promotional activity—identifying demand shifts before they appear in sales data. The differentiation extends beyond technology to deep retail operations expertise, with implementation designed by merchandising professionals who understand buying cycles and store operations. The system adapts to each retailer's unique assortment, customer base, and market dynamics, delivering localized predictions that reflect individual location characteristics.

2.name: Phase 2: Product & Experience
2.description: Detail the integration, user journey, and trust mechanisms that ensure user adoption and confidence.
2.contributors: VP of Merchandising, Store Managers, Inventory Planners, CFO

questions.text: How does the solution integrate into their existing workflows and systems?
questions.criteria: Merchandising system connectivity, point-of-sale data ingestion, supply chain integration, external signal incorporation, replenishment automation
questions.focus: Detail seamless connection to existing retail systems and automated demand-driven replenishment within current workflows.
questions.hint_text: Explain native connections to existing merchandising, point-of-sale, and warehouse management systems. Mention automatic ingestion of external signals like weather and events. Describe how forecasts flow directly into replenishment and allocation processes.
questions.ideal_answer: The platform integrates seamlessly with existing merchandising and supply chain systems through standard retail connectors, automatically ingesting point-of-sale data, inventory positions, and on-order quantities without manual data transfers. External demand signals—weather forecasts, local event calendars, social media trends, and competitive intelligence—flow continuously into the prediction engine, enriching forecasts with real-time context. Demand predictions automatically feed into replenishment systems and allocation workflows, enabling buyers to review AI-generated recommendations within their familiar tools. Store operations receive optimized allocation guidance through existing distribution channels, and the platform synchronizes with promotional planning systems to anticipate campaign-driven demand accurately, ensuring merchandising teams work within established processes.

questions.text: What does the user experience look like for different stakeholders or personas at the customer?
questions.criteria: Buyer recommendation clarity, store manager inventory visibility, planner forecast transparency, executive performance reporting, role-specific actionability
questions.focus: Compare actionable buyer replenishment recommendations with strategic executive inventory health dashboards.
questions.hint_text: Describe intuitive replenishment recommendations for buyers showing what to order and why versus inventory health dashboards for planners. Explain store-level visibility for managers and strategic inventory metrics for executives.
questions.ideal_answer: Buyers receive clear replenishment recommendations for each SKU and location, showing suggested order quantities with explanations of the demand signals driving each forecast—upcoming weather changes, local events, trending social activity. Store managers access location-specific inventory guidance highlighting products likely to stock out soon and slow movers requiring promotional attention. Planners view forecast accuracy metrics across categories and regions, identifying where predictions are performing well and where manual oversight may be needed. Executives see strategic dashboards quantifying stockout reduction, excess inventory improvement, working capital efficiency gains, and forecast accuracy trends, providing visibility into how demand intelligence is improving financial performance across the organization.

questions.text: What safeguards and controls give them confidence in the AI's outputs?
questions.criteria: Forecast confidence intervals, override capabilities, demand driver transparency, anomaly detection, performance tracking, feedback incorporation
questions.focus: Explain demand driver transparency and merchant override capabilities that build trust in AI recommendations.
questions.hint_text: Highlight how the system shows which signals are driving each forecast and provides confidence ranges. Describe merchant override capabilities and how the system learns from corrections. Explain anomaly flagging for unusual predictions.
questions.ideal_answer: Every forecast includes confidence ranges and transparent explanations showing which demand signals are influencing predictions—buyers understand why quantities are recommended rather than accepting black-box outputs. Merchants retain full override authority, adjusting recommendations based on their category expertise and market knowledge, with the system learning from these corrections to improve future predictions. Unusual forecasts that deviate significantly from patterns are automatically flagged for review before impacting orders. Performance dashboards track forecast accuracy against actual sales across categories and timeframes, providing ongoing validation of prediction reliability. Buyers can simulate different scenarios and see how forecasts respond to promotional timing or pricing changes, building confidence through transparency and control.

3.name: Phase 3: Execution & Scale
3.description: Outline the roadmap for success, evidence of performance, and the support model for organizational-wide rollout.
3.contributors: VP of Merchandising, Store Managers, Inventory Planners, CFO

questions.text: What does success look like at 90 days, 6 months, and 12 months?
questions.criteria: Pilot category validation, multi-category expansion, enterprise-wide adoption, organizational capability building, measurable financial transformation
questions.focus: Map pilot category validation milestones toward enterprise-wide intelligent merchandising transformation.
questions.hint_text: Define progression from pilot category with validated forecast improvement to expanded category coverage to company-wide demand intelligence standard. Show evolution from tactical inventory optimization to strategic merchandising capability.
questions.ideal_answer: At the initial milestone, success means validating the approach on pilot categories with measurable forecast accuracy improvement, documented stockout reduction, and buyer confidence in recommendations. Expansion phase success involves scaling across additional merchandise categories and store formats, with demand intelligence fully integrated into replenishment workflows and demonstrated performance across diverse product types. Full maturity represents the platform operating as the enterprise-wide demand forecasting standard, with intelligent inventory optimization embedded in merchandising culture. Leadership reports substantial working capital efficiency gains, improved gross margins from optimized inventory positioning, and enhanced competitive responsiveness through superior demand sensing that enables faster reaction to market opportunities.

questions.text: What evidence do we have that this works for companies like them?
questions.criteria: Retail segment relevance, operational scale similarity, validated performance metrics, independent verification, industry recognition
questions.focus: Reference comparable retail environment results and independently validated inventory optimization outcomes.
questions.hint_text: Mention deployments in similar retail segments with comparable assortment complexity. Describe validated stockout reduction and inventory efficiency improvements. Reference third-party validation or industry recognition of results.
questions.ideal_answer: The platform has proven success across retail environments similar to yours, with documented results in comparable merchandise categories and operational complexity. Reference customers report substantial stockout reduction while simultaneously decreasing excess inventory, with outcomes validated through financial audits confirming working capital improvements. Several implementations have been recognized by industry analysts for merchandising excellence and inventory optimization achievements. The approach has delivered consistent results across diverse retail formats—from specialty retailers to multi-category operations—demonstrating effectiveness across different assortment strategies and customer bases. Retail references are available to discuss their transformation from reactive to predictive merchandising and the financial impact they have realized.

questions.text: How will we support them through adoption and scale?
questions.criteria: Dedicated implementation support, buyer training programs, technical assistance accessibility, continuous optimization process, executive success reviews
questions.focus: Outline dedicated retail success team support and comprehensive merchant enablement programs.
questions.hint_text: Detail implementation support from retail merchandising experts. Describe hands-on buyer training and ongoing technical assistance. Explain continuous forecast optimization and regular business reviews tracking financial impact.
questions.ideal_answer: Your merchandising team receives dedicated implementation support from specialists combining data science and retail buying expertise, configuring the system for your specific assortment structure and market dynamics. Comprehensive training prepares buyers to interpret demand signals and work effectively with AI recommendations, with practical sessions using real merchandise decisions. Continuous technical support provides rapid assistance whenever questions arise during planning cycles. Regular optimization sessions analyze forecast performance, refine models based on your evolving assortment, and identify new opportunities to enhance prediction accuracy. Executive business reviews track key performance indicators—forecast accuracy trends, stockout reduction, inventory efficiency gains, and financial impact—ensuring leadership maintains visibility into how demand intelligence is strengthening merchandising outcomes and financial performance.
